makers.displaymaker: John La Farge, 1835–1910; born New York, NY; died Newport, RI

texts.textentryhtml:
Durand-Ruel sale (according to H. LaFarge).;

Exhibited at The Art Club in Philadelphia.;

La Farge was already an established and influential artist and decorative designer in 1890 when he embarked on a fifteen-month trip with the historian John Adams to explore the exotic culture and landscape of the South Seas. South Sea Dance, Samoa—probably based on photographs sold to tourists—conveys a more conventional and reportorial approach to indigenous peoples and their surroundings.
texts.remarks: Painting on Paper: American Watercolors at Princeton

texts.textentryhtml: In 1890, at the height of his career, the artist and stained-glass designer John La Farge was invited by the American historian Henry Brooks Adams to join him on a fifteen-month tour of the Pacific Islands. Traveling as tourists in relative luxury, Adams and La Farge visited Hawaii, Samoa, Tahiti, Fiji, Indonesia, and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) before returning to New York in the fall of 1891. La Farge filled his journals with notes and sketches, and executed meticulous watercolors—often based on photographs—that convey an anthropological approach to the exotic locations he visited, as well as the indigenous peoples, and their cultures, that he encountered.

bibliography.boilertext: Elisabeth Hodermarsky, et. al., John La Farge’s second paradise: voyages in the South Seas, 1890-1891, (New Haven, CT: Yale University Art Gallery: in association with Yale University Press, 2010).

bibliography.citation: Barbara T. Ross, American Drawings in the Art Museum, Princeton University: 130 Selected Examples (Princeton: Art Museum, Princeton University, 1976)., p. 74, no. 73; p. 75 (illus.)
